They were based on JEE Main pattern, but questions were above Main level.The thing was, I was not prepared for full syllabus, also, I lacked in the chapters I have studied also. I joined a coaching institute in mid-June 2019 and started my preparation from July, although my study time was not like other aspirants, it was rather 1–2 hours daily, nothing near a dropper is expected to have.I was scoring 150–160 in coaching tests initially, that came down to 130–140 by November, but they were not full syllabus test. They were based on JEE Main pattern, but questions were above Main level.The thing was, I was not prepared for full syllabus, also, I lacked in the chapters I have studied also. Also, I realise that the thing I lacked during my preparation wasAh, so I gave my exam onI find Physics a bit difficult, chemistry was also tough as I left organic and ignored NCERT. I think maths is the subject, where I scored the highest (comparitively) and I left some very easy questions, due to unkown reasons. I started my paper with Physics, then jumped to chemistry, then back to Physics, then I started Maths and then finished rest of chemistry.I attempted 46 questions in all,My result btw:I don't think this is enough to even clear the cut-off. Last year I scored 84.6 percentile in January and 74 percentile in April ( I went there with no seriousness).Wish me luck.Any kind of suggestion is welcome❤️Edit 1:Warning:Edit 2 (12 Sept 2020):I tried hard but lockdown had its impact on my studies and I find myself guilty for wasting this opportunity. I tried and scored around 110, but due to bad normalisation, I scored even less than last time (when I scored 71) , so, I didn't even clear my cut-off. I scored 87.7 this time.One reason behind this may be reduced number of students, because I was ahead of 87.7% of students out of 635k that appeared this time, which means around 78k rank, but after combining it with January, January score dominanted and I secured 128k rank.I won't get anything with that, I know (General student here).Just hope that I find some decent college through UPSEE, else I will be out of options, I have no idea what will happen now.I just know that it'll all be over by next month, things will get finalized anyway.Thanks for reading, I am open to any kind of suggestion.

Answer: I started my first company when I was 19.I literally started with a Google search, how to start a company.I had the idea to create the first leather watch strap without holes.It’d work like a zip-tie and allow for twice as many sizing options.All I had was this idea.Most people would stop there.I didn’t.Instead my first step was to get a sample made.I used to live in China and speak Mandarin so that’s what I did.I found a factory which could produce this product.At the time, I didn’t really know what I was doing.So I contacted Andy Laats, the founder of Nixon watches. They’re a $400 million doI started my first company when I was 19.I literally started with a Google search, how to start a company.I had the idea to create the first leather watch strap without holes.It’d work like a zip-tie and allow for twice as many sizing options.All I had was this idea.Most people would stop there.I didn’t.Instead my first step was to get a sample made.I used to live in China and speak Mandarin so that’s what I did.I found a factory which could produce this product.At the time, I didn’t really know what I was doing.So I contacted Andy Laats, the founder of Nixon watches. They’re a $400 million dollar watch company.I thought this meeting would give me all the answers.It took me six months to land this meeting.When we met, I felt like a idiot.Looking back on it, I was asking him the most basic questions about ecommerce.I really had no clue what I was doing.He probably left thinking my company would remain an idea.(We met before I had my first sample).Flash forward a year and my company was doing just over six figures in sales.I then heard of a talk Andy was giving.I went to the talk and stayed after, eager to catch up with him.As I approached, he said, man you look familiar!He was stoked that I had actually turned my idea into my own business.Andy gets requests to meet with hundreds of entrepreneurs a year. Most don’t go forward with the next steps of starting a company.Most first time entrepreneurs get caught up and don’t actually grow.They expect a mentor or coach to do the work for them.First time entrepreneurs need to know that there isn’t a magic box or person with all the answers.Your path to success will be different than someone else’s.Finding your own way is part of the journey.Though having a great mentor can help, you can’t expect them to do the work for you.The watch strap I invented!

Answer: 2 Top NIT Colleges in India:The Government of India funds NIT Rourkela, which is one of India's leading national-level institutions. It is a deemed university that belongs to the Association of Indian Universities (AIU) and has received a 'A' grade from the NAAC. Admissions are2 Top NIT Colleges in India:The Government of India funds NIT Rourkela, which is one of India's leading national-level institutions. It is a deemed university that belongs to the Association of Indian Universities (AIU) and has received a 'A' grade from the NAAC. India Today placed this institute 21st in the field of Engineering (Government) in 2021.NIT Rourkela offers undergraduate programmes such as BTech and BArch, as well as postgraduate courses such as integrated MSc, MTech, MBA, and PhD programmes in a variety of specialisations. Admissions are available in undergraduate, postgraduate, and doctoral programmes at the National Institute of Technology Rourkela. Students who wish to apply for admission to NIT Rourkela can do so online using the institute's official website. International students can also apply for UG and PG programmes through the Direct Admission of Students from Abroad programme (DASA).Goldman Sachs, Microsoft, Myntra, Amazon, Bajaj, Intel, Ford, and other top hiring firms visited NIT Rourkela.In the NIRF Ranking 2020, the National Institute of Technology (NIT) Kurukshetra is ranked 40th among India's top engineering colleges, and 27th by Week 2020. NIT Kurukshetra is well-known for its B.Tech programme, which is among the extensive range of courses offered. Admission to NIT Kurukshetra for B.Tech is exclusively based on JEE Main scores, followed by JoSAA Counseling.Course :BACHELOR OF TECHNOLOGY [B.TECH]Highlights of NIT Kurukshetra's B.Tech ProgramThe B.Tech programme at NIT Kurukshetra is available in seven different specialisations.The JEE Main rank is used to determine admission to NIT Kurukshetra's B.Tech programme.Candidates must register individually for the JoSAA Counseling, which determines seat allocation.Foreigners in UG/PG programmes at NIT Kurukshetra are admitted using the DASA (Direct Admission of Students Abroad) system, which is based on SAT scores.CSAB offers admission to B.Tech. programmes to Indian nationals (Central Seat Allocation Board)Chandigarh University (CU) was founded in 2012 by the Punjab State Legislature and is a UGC-accredited institution. CU is one among India's top higher education institutes due to its professional and academic excellence. The NAAC gave Chandigarh Institution a "A+" in the first cycle of accreditation, making it the first and only private university to do so.Chandigarh University creates over 5000 placement offers for its students in the midst of the pandemic. With 5000+ job offers for the 2021 graduating class, Chandigarh University's predicted success during COVID-19 has once again proved the varsity's mettle in Northern India's campus placements. Since over 500 worldwide firms completed tests, the global COVID-19 outbreak appears to be having minimal effect.Ranked among Asia’s best and fastest - growing universities, Chandigarh University’s performance speaks for itself . Over the years, the varsity has earned recognitions from top regulatory bodies, awards and accolades from various national and international organizations for the quality of our programs. These awards and recognitions further ensure top-notch opportunities for our students.Best Engineering College in Punjab:UIE, Punjab's Best Engineering College, is unique in that it gets its strength and motivation from top-tier blue-chip worldwide corporations. CU has set standards for engineering education since its inception and is one of Punjab's Best Engineering Colleges. Engineers capable of meeting the real-world demands of their profession and providing the best solutions for the betterment of society have been produced as a result of our dynamic hands-on experiential learning based engineering education and flexible academic model, which fosters imagination and innovation.

Answer: Grammatical mistakes can be easy to make. But fear not! Our team at Grammarly has compiled a handy list of common grammatical errors to help make your writing accurate, clear, and professional.Ambiguous (“Squinting”) modifiersA squinting modifier is a misplaced modifier that, because of its location in a sentence, could modify either the phrase that precedes it or the one that follows it. In the example sentence, is the subject listening to music slowly or slowly gettGrammatical mistakes can be easy to make. But fear not! Our team at Grammarly has compiled a handy list of common grammatical errors to help make your writing accurate, clear, and professional.Ambiguous (“Squinting”) modifiersA squinting modifier is a misplaced modifier that, because of its location in a sentence, could modify either the phrase that precedes it or the one that follows it. In the example sentence, is the subject listening to music slowly or slowly getting a headache? To correct a squinting modifier, move its position in the sentence to clarify to the reader which word you intend to modify.Misuse of lie/layIf you plan to place or put an object somewhere, such as a plate on a table, you should use “lay.” If you intend to stretch out on a bed for a nap, you should use “lie.” The verb “lie” is an intransitive verb, which means it does not need an object. The transitive verb “lay” requires an object.It may take some getting used to this “lay” or “lie” business; after all, misuse of these verbs is common. But if you remember to lay down your fork before you’re full, then you won’t have to lie down later from overeating.Comma splicesHe was very hungry, so he ate a whole pizza.To splice means to connect or join. When a writer joins two independent sentences with a comma instead of separating them with a period or coordinating conjunction, that’s a comma splice.The comma has its jobs to do, but connecting two independent sentences isn’t one of them. Besides, the period gets testy when his sister, the comma, steals his thunder. Periods have their jobs, and so do commas, but never the twain shall meet—unless it’s in the form of a semicolon. Semicolons can also take the place of a coordinating conjunction, such as “and,” “but,” or “so,” among others.Run-on sentencesRun-on sentences, also known as fused sentences, occur when two complete sentences are squashed together without using a coordinating conjunction or proper punctuation, such as a period or a semicolon. Run-on sentences can be short or long. A long sentence isn’t necessarily a run-on sentence.To avoid run-on sentences, see if there is more than one idea communicated by two or more independent clauses. In our examples, there are two complete sentences:Example:Example:Both sentences are complete ideas by themselves; therefore, use a semicolon or a period to indicate that they are separate independent clauses.Using “could of” instead of “could have”“Could have” is always correct; “could of” never is. Writers probably make this grammar gaffe because, when we speak, the contraction “could’ve” sounds an awful lot like “could of.”TautologiesTautologies express the same thing twice with different words. In our example, the word “made” implies that Jack used his own two hands to create the pail. The prepositional phrase “with his own hands” creates a redundancy. Once you know what they are, it’s fun to discover tautologies: dilapidated ruins, close proximity, added bonus, large crowd...The list goes on and on!After reading through this list of common grammatical mistakes, you might be wondering how to remember all these rules as you write. Answer: The short answer is that the people are really nice, the longer answer is that Haverford turns nerdy outcast types into charming and successful adults, and because I went to a liberal arts school the full answer could go on for pages.I went to Haverford for a couple of reasons.  First, I was legitimately struck during my visit by how friendly and supportive everybody was.  I did not have a pleasant experience in high school, and Haverford seemed like it would be a place where good people help each other.  Now, Haverford still exists in the real world, and not everybody is just lovely to be aroThe short answer is that the people are really nice, the longer answer is that Haverford turns nerdy outcast types into charming and successful adults, and because I went to a liberal arts school the full answer could go on for pages.I went to Haverford for a couple of reasons.  First, I was legitimately struck during my visit by how friendly and supportive everybody was.  I did not have a pleasant experience in high school, and Haverford seemed like it would be a place where good people help each other.  Now, Haverford still exists in the real world, and not everybody is just lovely to be around all the time, but I did find, by and large, that my initial impression was accurate.  The freshman hall experience (called Customs) is intense enough that you're basically handed 8-16 friends straight off the bat, and very few people go through their freshman year alone, especially in contrast to other colleges.  As a personal contrast, I went to NYU for law school, and I was struck by how socially acceptable it was there to be an asshole.  It wasn't considered a positive attribute, but it also wasn't socially damning.  At Haverford, assholes are unpopular.  (And excuse my language.)The second reason I went is that Haverford is small enough (roughly 1100 students when I went, and I think it's similar now) that you really feel like you know everyone.  I recall on my visit seeing some dude barreling around a corner and running into someone.  After he helped her pick up her stuff, he started talking to her about something that, even from out of earshot, was obviously unrelated to what he just did.  I thought about it and realized that I would love to go to a college where you would have something you want to talk about with someone you literally run into.  This cuts both ways -- it's a lot more intimidating to make a move on your crush when you know, win, lose or draw, that everyone will find out by Monday -- but by senior year (actually, by sophomore year) you really know who your friends are in your class, and you have a bond with everyone that I don't think happens at every college.As a side note, I did pretty well in school and expected to be one of the smarter people at Haverford.  I was wrong.  The academics there are strong, sure, but I just loved being around really smart people all the time.So those are the differences that made me go there.  By the time I left, I liked to say that Haverford was a place for turning dorks into actual adults.  Now, there are some popular-kid types at Haverford (and they're lovely), but I found that almost everyone there had some level of being both friendly and nerdy, however easily they might mask it with good looks, athletic accomplishment, or what have you.  And some people (here's where I came in) showed up at Haverford being, again, friendly and nerdy, but not necessarily the most socially adept.  And something about being in a positive environment of like-minded people helps a lot of Haverford students come out of their shell, become more confident, and leave as a (mostly) fully functioning adult.  Put more obnoxiously, there are colleges out there that are women-only (like our twin school Bryn Mawr) where, presumably, women go to gain confidence and leadership skills in a supportive environment.  Plenty of HBCUs out there do the same for African-Americans.  Honestly, I think Haverford is like that for nerds.  I'm really glad I went there.
name: Vidhi Khandel
